title: @Riot: Why didn't you annihilate the Institute of War instead of retconning it?
body:
I understand that the writers were having a lot of frustration with the Lore up to that point and how the Institute of War, the League of Legends, was constraining the world they wanted to create. However, was retconning the entire lore really the best idea, both for continuity for players and work load?

Why wasn't the Institute of War utterly annihilated or simply vanished from the world, summoners and all, without a trace?

This would have had the world and lore be mostly in the same place we have currently have, maybe with a short time skip to move the world further forwards, but without the need to retcon so many stories that were connected directly to the IoW and summoners, like Jax, Lee Sin, and Ionian Boots of Lucidity to name but a few.

This also opens up new stories as Demacia, Noxus, Shurima, and all the other city states new and old have to deal with the loss of the major super power that kept balance on the continent for so long and the impending threats like the Harrowing, more and new Void spawn, the Watchers, and everything else as well as each other.

This also explains why Bard has suddenly appeared after being gone for ages. Without the Institute of War to force their balance, the world is shifting quickly towards utter annihilation, who's appearance currently doesn't seem clear or well explained. In fact, Bard almost seems like the Institute of War itself in the from of a champion based on his lore.

replies.body:
As a former Dawngate player, want to comment on this piece:

>The idea that players could influence the story was pretty misleading – at any “story match,” only ten players would legitimately get to fulfill the role of a summoner. In addition, story by vote or story by chance can often end with unsatisfying results (simply because of the random chance). Strong storytelling is deeply crafted.

Dawngate proved to me that player-driven stories CAN work, and work amazingly well.

Dawngate used a serial webcomic as it's storytelling (and promotions) vehicle. It had three-to-four interwoven plot lines and when a character hit a crossroads they put the decision to a player vote by using games played to decide (you make your pick, play games, and the more games and wins you get the more votes you contribute).

But the trick to it is, the player story choices never quite played out how you expected. There was a twist to how it came about.

When Zalgus and Raina had to choose between obeying the mission of their Queen to travel to Maridia as envoys, or to delay their arrival to investigate an attack on the abbey where their childhood friend Kindra lived, players chose to have them travel to the abbey.

Now, players already knew from Kindra's backstory in her profile what was going on: Kinda's backstory is that she slaughtered the sisters of her abbey and became a shadowy assassin. So what we *expected* of the Kindra story was that Zalgus and Raina catch Kindra in the act of slaughter.

What happened instead is this: Zalgus and Raina arrive at the abbey in the aftermath. Bodies are being burned on a pyre, the abbey is a wreck. They investigate, and Zalgus learns the truth of their childhood friend through clairvoyance magic but spares his sister (Raina) that knowledge. They find a little girl, traumatized and terrified, hidden behind some rubble.

This little girl, however, was a Shaper. The spirit of Terror had bound to her, taking the form of a large wave of ectoplasm.

The terrified little girl lashed out at Raina and Zalgus with tendrils of glowing slime, scattering everything around her. Raina, whose spirit was Preservation, called up shards of stained glass from a broken window and empowered them into a shield to defend themselves until the girl wore herself out and collapsed. They carried her out of the abbey to safety.

So instead of the expected story of Zalgus and Raina catching Kindra doing the atrocities we already knew she did, we got a new character introduced who would have been a playable shaper down the line, and a new Raina skin themed around that stained glass shield.

Player Choices brought about that story path. A new skin and a new character came about from our decisions, but with the way the writing was handled, it still felt engaging. Emotional investment of the readers was still a huge part of it. It was player choice that was ALSO deeply crafted.

What I am getting at is, you CAN have it both ways. Engaging the players directly in a compelling story to flesh out the gameplay was an amazing thing, and I'd love to see Riot pursue it.

A critical question to ask here is...

Is Runaan even still employed with Riot? Googling for her name gave me her Twitter and Reddit accounts, but none of those have been updated for a very long time. Her Twitter account only contains one link from March 2015, and her Reddit account seems to have remained untouched since last November.

I feel this is a critical question to ask because none of the other members of the narrative team from that time are still around. Jaredan gave a frustratingly obfuscated answer when asked about it, but other evidence speaks louder than that. Opeli hasn't posted around these parts for at least three months and her Twitter account has been deleted, while Tom Abernathy - the previous senior narrative designer - has rather loudly quit some months ago, and his biting and dismissive remarks hinted that he might have been fired over the negative response to the retcon/reboot/whatever you may call it.

The thing is, just because that was the explanation way back then, doesn't mean it's *still* the explanation six months later, especially given that huge parts of the narrative team have swapped out and Riot Games doesn't actually have a senior narrative designer (which means they don't have a narrative direction either).

Unless there is something very different about how Riot operates, one doesn't really hire two Senior Narrative Designers to work on a single game. That's like having two chefs in one kitchen or two directors on one movie. The purpose of the SND is to make sure that the work of the entire narrative department flows together into a single vision, therefore two narrative designers is detrimental to a cohesive project because there would be two separate visions.

That said, the first time someone spotted that position on the career list was about a month or two after Tom Abernathy quit. In addition, one of Abernathy's last comments on Riot Games was a scathing claim that the position of a narrative lead doesn't exist within the company. It's safe to assume that they're trying to employ a new Senior Narrative Designer after Abernathy quit, just like it would be safe to assume that Riot has been operating without someone in that position for the last six months (therefore the extremely sluggish developments with narrative).

I said it before, but I don't envy them. It's pretty hard to find a senior narrative designer in this industry, let alone one with four years of experience. A narrative designer with that sort of pedigree would sooner join a company that specializes in story-driven games, since it would give them more opportunity to showcase their work and turn their name into a brand. Not only that, but joining a company that so recently had a huge public controversy regarding their narrative department is simply too much of a career risk.

Good digging on your part and that is some pretty sour news.

If it has been up for six months with no takers for a major position in an prominent company like Riot, than that means Mr. Abernathy's exit may have poisoned the well for Riot looking for established Senior Narrative Designers. If that is the case Riot will be hard pressed to get a Senior Narrative Designer unless there is a public and internal shift in their management and company relating to lore.

They might be able to find someone if they knock down their expectations a little bit. Expecting a senior narrative designer *with four years experience* to apply for a position in a company that is only responsible for a single game, one that is not story-driven and has recently very loudly divorced itself from its own lore, is completely bonkers.

Most of the video game writers with so much experience are either already spoken for (Chris Avellone, David Gaider, Jeffrey Yohalem) or are being offered work from all directions (Rhianna Pratchett, Tom Jubert, Jonas Kyratzes). In the latter case, locking themselves into a single company would actually hurt their income and public exposure.

Part of it, but not a good explanation for why the vanishing concept was never considered, where all the summoners and IoW are removed from Runeterra by some unknown force, which would have been a change almost as large as the retcon, but not deep effect the champions as was worried in the post, or the added work load of redesigned all the champions from square one instead of expanding them.

I can understand that a loss of the IoW would have had consequences to the world, but it would have also been a perfect way to introduce Bard as he was presented since he was already in development at the time, as well as Shurima and the Harrowing as it makes them feel even more impactful now that there isn't anyone to 'keep the peace'.
A random thought just crossed my mind, was Bard's story modified to make him the new stand in the for the IoW after it was removed or was that the plan before the retcon?

The post speaks about the valuing the storytelling about characters but then also says that a story about a 'crumbling' IoW would effect their characters deeply, which is a good thing you want for storytelling, unless you want your character to be mostly, if not completely, stagnate.
That actually raises more questions now on how and if they plan to advance to story in a meaningful way.

Yes, it was stagnate, but I don't see much of a change. It has been eight months since the retcon, more than half a year, and while the champions are being presented differently with grand introductions, aside from Azir (Edit: and Bard) they don't seem out of place if the IoW was still around since the whole argument at the time is that he would never join.

I can understand that the IoW was a crutch, but so is the retcon. If they had explored some aftermath of a Runeterra without an IoW, however small, it would have expanded the story instead of restarting it. I can understand Disney doing this with Star Wars' expanded universe since that is **massive** and instead picking the best parts out of it or making nods to it, but Riot has a deep understanding on their lore, its history, and can use it to turn that 'duct tape' into something solid. Remember, even if you build you house where the old one was, it will not be truly 'home' until it is as lived in. The amount of content and insight into the champions and what they did was a fun part of the game, where you could say, "Ya, between fighter her sister, she runs a bakery." Little things like that which add more to the story and the depth of the characters than a few simple paragraphs for a bio.

Bard as presented in the lore is a confusing case. They spend all this money on an amazing animation to introduce Bard, then come out with three paragraphs that just says, people don't understand him and he keeps the balance of the world so it doesn't go boom. There isn't even a tease of a looming threat or foreshadowing for why Bard is here. He has been gone for **ages**, so long that only a few people even remember his symbol, and now he appears again to stop... something? His lore is currently the most shallow so far as he just seems to be the IoW stand in to fix things so it can't go too wrong.

If they don't finish that big 'lore upgrade' they have been working on by September, a full year since the retcon, I will have to say they announced the retcon _far_ too soon, as they have thrown off the life support, but are still stuck in crutches.

All of your opinion aside (plenty of us liked the League of Legends, and it worked fine as a vehicle for telling stories), the central problem remains that the storyline has been, according to your metaphor, homeless and malnourished for months. They haven't built anything on top of the vacant lot; they just bulldozed a functional if overcrowded house and haven't done anything with the rubble.

It actually *is* writing issues as well. The Narrative Team has been going without a Senior Narrative Designer for over six months now, ever since Tom Abernathy quit the position. They're about as healthy as a freshly beheaded chicken that's been running around a backyard and leaving blood and feathers everywhere.

Also, a whole bunch of members of the Narrative Team quit since the retcon announcement, so we can assume the chicken is missing wings and a leg as well.

Thankfully, Riot Games are like a mad doctor; they can revive the chicken if they frankenstein new wings and head onto its body. The problem is that they would need to *find* those wings and head first, and nobody is willing to give them a chicken head for some reason.

In the rare times when I actually have the creative energy on something other than my game, I've been entertaining the idea of writing a Rek'sai Judgment.

My idea was that rather than write an actual Judgment, I'd write a story of the Institute trying to capture her. So they employ several Summoners, as well as Sivir and Rengar (with Gnar tagging along) as the hunting strike force. The capture attempt goes bust, but one of the Summoners does manage to tag her with a beacon spell that allows one to summon her onto the Fields of Justice. From there, Malzahar the Great Void Ambassador manages to convince her into a certain degree of cooperation.

Bam, Rek'sai is still at large and occasionally posing a problem for Shurimans, the stories with her can be set both in and outside of the Institute, *and* she fits within the lore. Obviously only one way of handling the situation, but I think it serves as a fine example that there *are* ways to explain why Rek'sai is being summoned without being captive.

( Maybe she and Cho'Gath are dating and sometimes he lets her get summoned instead of him under the condition that she doesn't do anything that disrupts the long-term Voidborn agenda. See? Here's another solution. )

I do feel equipped to answer some of those with possible solutions.

1. "Could you just summon her into a volcano or something?" Summoning isn't the same as teleportation. While we do have cases of summoners teleporting champions in the Fields of Justice, we don't know if such free-range teleportation is available without a psychic link and a magically infused place like the Summoner's Rift. If it was, Valoran wouldn't have such problems as bandits and piracy because every major business would simply teleport their goods around. Poor Gangplank would be out of job.

2. Being unable to actually contain Rek'sai could be explained by the purple glow in her tunnels. Perhaps the reason why she can instantly cover huge distance by burrowing is because she can "burrow" through the fabric of reality, essentially creating void portals. Something like that would be *very* difficult to contain. Yes, they would be able to use the beacon to pull her back to the desired location, but doing that *every single time* she digs away would be an enormous waste of resources.

3. Given that we already have champions with completely alien mindsets in Fiddlesticks, Nocturne and Zyra, as well as complete lunatics like Renekton and Teemo, I imagine League would have summoners trained in handling the mental strain of linking up with *extremely* irregular cases.

And well the thing is Gangplank is out of job,his lore mentions that he had to give up piracy to become a champion :p.
But the big difference here is that Rek'sai is a monster,there is no reason for her to get any special protection from anyone and she makes a large part of shurima completely uninhabitable.The criminals of most city states are either not nearly enough of a problem or joined the league and thus gained protection from it.
